column18: I like that the modules are very detailed (except maybe for the w4 source code). I was able to understand the lectures because of the way the documentations were written
column19: The slides in the videos are not as sequential and as clear as the module (documentation in the source codes) so I get lost sometimes. However, the modules are very detailed and it helped a lot. I found the 4th week extra challenging though because everything seemed to be lumped together abruptly.
Try to add more math into it

column18: The only rewarding for this course is the weekly codes and datasets provided

In-depth discussion. I felt like the course was not beginner friendly, catered to those who are likely to already know the content.
focus on more useful activities and concepts
More step-by-step videos

column18: Learned the fundamentals of deep learning
column19: First, the lectures have to be organized better. Some discussions are really hard to digest. I think the lecturer could've reduced the technical aspect of the topic, and had more practical examples. Slides have code snippets that are unreadable. Visualizations of processes of deep learning techniques were ineffective for me.
already good

column18: Was able to learn a lot about Neural Nets

More examples please
Turn around time on results of assessments is abysmal.

column18: Able to run the codes given each week
column19: Kindly include the step by step process of creating the code, its hard to appreciate the lesson without understanding why a certain block of code perform the task mentioned. Focus on simplifying things and covering the basics rather than trying to cover all but not simplifying as much as possible

column18: Course emphasizes a conceptual understanding of deep learning and features many useful tools enabled by Keras and TensorFlow
column19:
A serious limitation of the course is that students can't proceed to the next peer-graded assessment if they haven't received a passing grade from the assessment of the previous week. It took around 4-6 weeks to get a grade for each assessment, even as I attempted to give the maximum possible number of assessments (around 12-16) to try and reduce the peer grading backlog. Please consider opening assessments so that students can proceed to the next week's assessment without having to wait for a grade from their previous week's assessment.

Video lectures are difficult to understand, especially for beginners. Most videos seem to be inadequate summaries of corresponding sections of the "Deep Learning with Python" by Fran?ois Chollet and are extremely difficult to learn from without consulting the source material. The videos should be recreated with more thorough explanation.

Assessments also involve only slight tweaks to the sample codes presented in lecture, so perhaps it would be better to include prompts that encourage exploration (e.g. have students try to identify why particular metrics change when varying specific hyperparameters).
i would like to suggest to provide more study materials and a rigorous discussion on the codes used in the lectures

column18: Knowing new things about deep learning; getting to run code from instructional material
column19: Fix the presentations and slides. Some look like they're not prepared well. Also, assessment instructions are vague. Lastly, improve on presenting. It's like we're just reading codes. And if we're reading codes, sometimes it isn't related to what the instructor is saying. Maybe provide graphical illustrations.

column18: The explanation of the instructor is very concise
column19: more examples of the defined deep learning models
better delivery (simpler explanation using analogy)
elaborate more on the lectures.. explain as much as possible

Use and build your own lecture. The SME uses others work. You can search it.
